title: CID-12472 PYI Manual | Invalid Video can be uploaded
description:
## What does this MR do?

Issue spotted during development of CID-9402. Spotted that the test file "sample_invalid_video.mov" from the PYI repo can be uploaded and submitted. This shouldn't be allowed as the file is invalid.

We need to fix this issue and ensure that we have an API Test that covers this scenario so we can ensure that we don't reintroduce this issue again in the future.

Notes from Matthew Clark re the issue:
A bug has been found in spa-shell, media-validation.services.ts file. In the isMediaValid method, the condition for checking a ShortestDimensionFail, fails to resolve an error when the shortestDimension variable is undefined (on line 42). The front end continues to progress loading the video.

## Related issues (CID-12472)

https://nhsd-jira.digital.nhs.uk/browse/CID-12472

Traded phonenumbers for phonenumberslite
description:
`phonenumbers` has a smaller brother (same project, same top package name)  
`phonenumberslite` : literally a drop-in replacement if you don't use the extended data (which we don't)

- 5MB vs 20MB of zipped space
- We don't use the extended provider info
- Still passes tests

PLUS

- Updated some lockfiles
  - Where project hash didn't match
  - Where library hash from nexus mismatched

title: WIP: Testing updating the same record with a partial model
Fix/crypto shenanigans
description:
- `python-jose` works best with `cryptography`
- This isn't installed by default
- With it, you can get shot of `rsa`, `ecdsa` and `pyasn1`
  - All of these frequently stink up our NexusIQ reports
- Hooray

Also

- Updates build system to latest scripts

---

Improved explanation!

- `python-jose` needs cryptographic libs to do things with JWTs
- The best ones are the native `cryptography` libs
- These are not the defaults and need to be specified as a Python "extra"
- Once you have `cryptography`, you can remove the Python-only `rsa`, `ecdsa` and `pyasn1` libraries as they aren't used
  - These python libs are slower and frequently generate security advisories

This change adds `cryptography` as an extra to `python-jose`, and adds the data that the build system uses to manually remove the "bad" python-only libraries.

title: CID-5489 HTML5 for certain Samsung and Firefox browser
WIP: Cid 10586/fix common libs dependencies
description:
## Use internal PyPi mirror as default

Without the `default = true` in the Poetry config, the public PyPi repo will get used by default. My oversight.

## Fix versioning

- All explicit, fixed version numbers have been converted to ranges
- OR local path references with `develop = true` for in-tree dependencies

This won't change lockfiles or `requirements.txt` outside the tree, which still fix a specific version, but it does mean that you get the intuitive behaviour - that if you make a change to e.g. cid-logger, that change then gets reflected immediately when used from e.g. common-cid tests.

## Fix build

- `helper_shas.sh` fetched back the full output of `aws ssm get-parameter` which is a JSON blob rather than a hash string

~~This means that all packages would have been re-published every time, because a JSON blob != a sha256sum~~

Above was wrong - `grep` was being used to find the current source hash in the JSON blob. But equality is a better test.

It was also vulnerable to including build byproducts `*.pyc`, etc in the sha sum, so the `find` command has been tweaked to avoid them

- Moved all build detail into the Makefile
  - The `build_spec.yaml` file knew the list of packages
  - The shell scripts knew actions
  - The Makefile knew other stuff
  - This meant you had to look at and think about 6 files to maintain the build system
  - Now the Makefile knows all

NexusIQ scan was busted because it needs either a `requirements.txt` or (ideally) a set of wheels to scan, and this build places neither in the working folder (Poetry stores venvs out of tree by default). Added a build target that copies all the required wheels into a local folder for Nexus to scan. This also happily excludes things that Nexus doesn't know how to cope with like - our libraries, it's own client JAR file, etc.

In order to keep checking for security vulnerabilities, all code is installed and then tested, every run instead of just when it's changed - you need to pull all the wheels anyway because vulnerabilities don't wait for you to change your code. Testing after doing this adds very minimal overhead.

## Publishing

```sh
# Publishes all packages that are different compared to their SSM hash
make publish_new
```

- [ ] Need to work out how to change this depending on branch
- [ ] Probably also need a versioning strategy

## Version Bump

This MR version bumps every lib here by a patch version.

It also provides make targets that use the `poetry version` command to perform this action more easily.

title: modified a user to have json string as connection token
Retool build to use a layer, remove insecure libraries.
description:
Ticket : [CID-9015](https://nhsd-jira.digital.nhs.uk/browse/CID-9015) Reduce Python storage requirements    
Environment : [dev15](https://eu-west-2.console.aws.amazon.com/codesuite/codepipeline/pipelines/dev15-acc-be/view?region=eu-west-2)

This MR follows much the same pattern as for the Java functions in PYI

- Pay some attention to the build system
- Create a base layer
- Eliminate the base layer libraries from lambda deployment packages

*NEW* - also gets rid of `jwt` and resolves the problems noted below. Getting rid of `jwt` also means the last attachment to the older `2.x.x` series of `cryptography` releases are gone. No more `jwt`, no more `python-jose-cryptodome`.

Also eliminates `abcplus`, which isn't needed for the abstract class markup, that's in the core libraries.

## Poetry

Have changed build system from pip + `requirements.txt` to [Poetry](https://python-poetry.org/).

This has some advantages that are a bit double-edged in places

- Pro : It has a really good dependency resolver (more akin to npm or yarn)!
- Con : It has a really good dependency resolver - and the dependency graph is a bit old and crufty.

This has exposed some contradictions, like `common-cid` requiring newer versions of the AWS SDK than all the `requirements.txt` in here (which has been fixed by upgrading these functions), but in the main allows for robust dependency resolution.

## Second try : Packages, packages everywhere

See : "First Try" below as to why this is the second try.

1. Created a `pyproject.toml` for each top package
   - Didn't attempt this for every single entrypoint, because that would be silly
     - But possible, if you really need to
1. We're not actually using `poetry build` though, we're using shell scripts
   - Use Poetry to create a `.venv`
   - De-reference any ~~`.egg-link`~~ `.pth` files caused by local dependencies
   - Archive it all up for distribution per-endpoint

This meant that we had to reorganize the source a little to fit with Poetry's conception of Python project layout.

```
my-project
|- pyproject.toml
|- my_project/
   - __init__.py
   - awesome_package.py
```



## First try : One Package to Rule Them All

First thought was to just create one `pyproject.toml` that described all dependency versions, and build a single lambda distribution package, the only variation being which handler function was selected.

This fell down because of two dependency clashes.

1. `python-jose` vs `python-jose-cryptodome`
1. `PyJWT` vs `jwt`

### `jose`

Both these packages declare a top package called `jose`.

The `cryptodome` fork of `python-jose` came about because it only supported the old and broken `pycrypto` ; `python-jose` now supports a variety of backends and the recommended backend is much more secure.

`python-jose-cryptodome` comes in via the `common-cid` library depending on `warrant` - this is pretty abandoned also and a newer fork, `pycognito`, pulls in `python-jose[cryptography]` instead.

### `jwt` vs `PyJWT`

Both of these declare a top package called `jwt`.

`PyJWT` comes in via the GOVUK notifier client for Python.

As an aside, `jwt` 0.5.4 also pulls in `typing`, which breaks any use of this package in Python runtimes that already include it (3.6 and above), so there's a kludge in here where we explicitly remove `typing` after installing it. Could upgrade to `0.6.1` or newer, but this dependency is declared in `common-cid`, so that's a different repo.

### Recommended actions

To resolve the above :

1. Replace `warrant` with `pycognito`
   - This gets you the newer `python-jose[cryptography]`
1. Replace `jwt` with `python-jose[cryptography]`
   - All the functions from `jwt` have equivalents in `python-jose`
   - They seem to work better / easier
     - e.g. you don't have to decode PEM files
     - e.g. it actually forces you to check audience claims (which we're making, but not checking, so that breaks things)

This removes all the top-namespace clashes and could allow One Package To Rule Them All, the main advantage of which is that
now *everything* (in this repo) is definitely using the same libraries.

The main reason I didn't just do this is because this would require changes to `common-cid` - and this will affect all the other clients of that library.

## TODOs

- [x] Move the unit tests out of the deployed packages
- [x] Make the "local" build less messy
  - Currently it leaves a lot of root-owned broken virtual environments and other detritus behind
- [x] Update the README.md with stuff about Poetry
